image.altText: A composite of a woman with long blonde hair, and a young person holding an Adidas sneaker.

items.synopsis: When Byron Bay woman Sarah Luke found out her personal details had been shared on the dark web, she never imagined it would lead to two US court actions and a million-dollar damages bill.

title.children: Data breach victim told to pay Adidas, National Basketball Association $US1.2m by US courts

image.altText: A composite image of Veena Sahajwalla on the left, Craig Reucassel in the middle and Nina Gbor on the right

items.synopsis: Ahead of tonight's premiere of War On Waste, host Craig Reucassel, eco stylist Nina Gbor and scientist Veena Sahajwalla are on deck to answer your recycling questions, bust myths, and provide the inspiration to take action.

title.children: From commercial to household rubbish — how can we fight the war on waste? Join our live Q&A

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What is a good way to start recycling? - Ainslie. Thanks for this question Ainslie! It's a great place to start for people who are looking to dip their toes in the world of recycling. This is Professor Veena Sahajwalla 's advice: If you want to do the right thing starting in your own home (or office or community), really take stock of all the things you have that are going to end up being disposed of in landfill. You can stop right there at the source and you can actually go ‘OK, whether it’s my metals that are in my aluminium products or if it’s my e-waste', all of these different kinds of products can actually be channelled towards solutions. You might be able to go back to your council about what they're doing with the waste. Of course, if you're not entirely happy with where your products might end up, ask questions of a few other councils and organisations in your area. Where products can be recycled or remanufactured, you can help that process by dropping them off at the right location and making sure you’re effectively enabling the entire ecosystem.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What is a good way to start recycling?

children.content: What is a good way to start recycling?
- Ainslie
Thanks for this question Ainslie! It's a great place to start for people who are looking to dip their toes in the world of recycling.
This is
Professor Veena Sahajwalla
's advice:

If you want to do the right thing starting in your own home (or office or community), really take stock of all the things you have that are going to end up being disposed of in landfill. You can stop right there at the source and you can actually go ‘OK, whether it’s my metals that are in my aluminium products or if it’s my e-waste', all of these different kinds of products can actually be channelled towards solutions.

You might be able to go back to your council about what they're doing with the waste. Of course, if you're not entirely happy with where your products might end up, ask questions of a few other councils and organisations in your area. Where products can be recycled or remanufactured, you can help that process by dropping them off at the right location and making sure you’re effectively enabling the entire ecosystem.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: One thing I was keen to get Craig's thoughts on was how much of a role he thinks big business and the commercial industry has to play in our war on waste. Here's what Craig says: The role that business plays is crucial. And government too. Yes, in the show we give tips for what you can do. But in a lot of cases the reason that higher recycling rates are not being met or waste avoided or emissions skyrocketing is out of our hands as individuals. It is in how packaging is designed. It is in how clothing is manufactured and marketed. It is what infrastructure has been built. It is in the energy used in manufacturing. So a lot of this series is focused on what business and government need to do to make the system work better. Australians have actually been pretty good at putting their recycling in their bins for years. It is time for the system to actually catch up to our expectations. Which doesn’t mean individuals don’t have a role, but one of those roles is demanding better from business and government.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How much of a role does big business play in our waste war?

children.content: One thing I was keen to get Craig's thoughts on was how much of a role he thinks big business and the commercial industry has to play in our war on waste.

props.alt: Craig Reucassel sitting at a desk in front of a laptop smiling

children.content: (ABC)
Here's what
Craig
says:

The role that business plays is crucial. And government too. Yes, in the show we give tips for what you can do. But in a lot of cases the reason that higher recycling rates are not being met or waste avoided or emissions skyrocketing is out of our hands as individuals. It is in how packaging is designed. It is in how clothing is manufactured and marketed. It is what infrastructure has been built. It is in the energy used in manufacturing.

So a lot of this series is focused on what business and government need to do to make the system work better. Australians have actually been pretty good at putting their recycling in their bins for years. It is time for the system to actually catch up to our expectations. Which doesn’t mean individuals don’t have a role, but one of those roles is demanding better from business and government.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Another question from the festival field, this time on sustainability. Here's Craig 's take: That’s a big question! From a waste perspective, reducing our food waste and keeping it out of landfill is a big thing we can do to be more sustainable. When food is uneaten we waste so many resources – the land, water, transport and energy that went into making it. And when we bury it in landfill, it breaks down without oxygen which creates methane, a potent greenhouse gas. So keeping our food waste out of landfill should be a priority for Australia. Reducing our use of single-use plastics is also a big goal. We can do some of this ourselves through changes in our habits (going reusable for water bottles and coffee cups etc) but it is very hard to avoid plastic in our society. So as long as it remains part of our world, we have to increase how much of it we actually recycle. Recycled plastic uses less energy and creates less emissions than virgin plastic. So, we have to get our plastic recycling above the pitiful 13% level that it's currently at. This takes companies designing better packaging and governments not only building recycling infrastructure (there has been a lot of new stuff already) but also putting in place rules to encourage recycling.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What everyday things can we do to be more sustainable?

children.content: Another question from the festival field, this time on sustainability.

Reducing our use of single-use plastics is also a big goal. So as long as it remains part of our world, we have to increase how much of it we actually recycle. Recycled plastic uses less energy and creates less emissions than virgin plastic. So, we have to get our plastic recycling above the pitiful 13% level that it's currently at. This takes companies designing better packaging and governments not only building recycling infrastructure (there has been a lot of new stuff already) but also putting in place rules to encourage recycling.

image.altText: The sign out of the front of the building and the crest, with an autumnal tree nearby and a blue sky beyond.

items.synopsis: Christopher Roy Weaver, 40, faces court nearly two years after the death of Laura Crncevic of a heroin overdose.

title.children: Canberra man charged with manslaughter over heroin overdose that killed partner nearly two years ago

image.altText: Two women stand smiling side by side with their arms around one another.

items.synopsis: Social enterprise Crafting My Story is aiming to create a supportive sisterhood of culturally diverse women in Australia and overseas making handmade, environmentally sustainable works.

title.children: Using crafting and a 'sisterhood' movement to remove barriers for multicultural women

image.altText: A composite photo of two women and two men.

items.synopsis: Police have laid out the chain of events they will allege led to a horror triple fatal north of the Sunshine Coast.

title.children: Good Samaritan chased into oncoming traffic before triple fatal crash, police allege

image.altText: A woman wearing a blue shirt and gloves kneels in the dirt next to a bucket as she reaches into a hole with a small tool

items.synopsis: More than eight decades after Australian soldiers were transferred from temporary graves on the Kokoda Track to a wartime cemetery, a chance discovery reveals the task was never quite completed.

title.children: Chance encounter reveals partial remains of Australian soldiers who died on the Kokoda Track

image.altText: A man wearing a tiger headdress and yellow robe

items.synopsis: Football fans wearing tiger headdresses, hair flowers and flowing yellow, blue and red flags have come from across Sydney to pump up the Colombian national team ahead of today's match.

title.children: 'Runs in our blood': Colombia fans promise passion ahead of Women's World Cup match against South Korea

image.altText: Natalie Keley wears a blue shirt at Go Between Bridge, where her sister Teisha Keley was found dead

items.synopsis: Many would have passed by the tangled mess of tents, swags and junk that made up a homeless camp along a riverside walkway in Brisbane's CBD, but no-one realised they were walking past a dead body.

title.children: Tragedy under a city bridge: How a homeless woman was neglected in death as she was in life

image.altText: large metal spikes are lined up in a row over a city street.

items.synopsis: The Ukrainian capital's military said its air defences have been engaged, after Kyiv claimed a drone attack on Moscow.

title.children: Russia launches attack on Kyiv as tensions boil in the region

image.altText: A serviceman with a Russian flag on his uniform stands guard near the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant wearing a face covering

items.synopsis: The International Atomic Energy Agency says mines were found in "restricted areas", and that any detonation should not affect the plant's nuclear safety and security systems.

title.children: Mines found at Ukraine's Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, UN watchdog says

image.altText: A group of people walk in shallow water in front of large orange floating buoys.

items.synopsis: The newly installed floating barrier on the Rio Grande is the Republican Governor Greg Abbott's latest tactic to try to stop migrants from crossing into the US from Mexico.

title.children: US sues Texas over floating border barriers designed to stop migrants

image.altText: Black and white photo of large crowd of people, many squinting into the sun, aboard a boat, just visible.

items.synopsis: In 1975, Indonesia troops invaded Timor-Leste, targeting, among others, the Chinese Hakka ethnic minority. These people remember what the day was like.

title.children: Four decades ago soldiers killed their family and friends. Today they celebrate their own survival

image.altText: A blonde white woman smiles in the front seat of a small pink convertable, next to a photo of a man in a hat smoking a cigarette

items.synopsis: Independent cinemas in regional Australia say the so-called Barbenheimer weekend led to a fourfold increase in ticket sales, which was much needed after the pandemic changed the way people watched movies.

title.children: Dual release of blockbusters Barbie and Oppenheimer a shot in the arm for independent cinemas

image.altText: Women wearing red soccer jerseys walking onto a green pitch

items.synopsis: Had Morocco qualified for the Women’s World Cup a decade ago, a player who wanted to wear the hijab during a game might have been forced to choose between faith and football.

title.children: Hijabs were only authorised by FIFA in 2014 — Nouhaila Benzina is the first to wear one at the Women's World Cup

image.altText: An older man and woman smile in front of a billboard showing a house that had been sold at an auction.

items.synopsis: Higher interest rates and rising house prices have not deterred migrants, retirees and first home buyers relying on "the bank of mum and dad" from buying property, despite data showing a lower number of property settlements.

title.children: The Lindemans bought their new home at auction — and paid in cash. They're part of a growing trend

image.altText: Pilot sitting in the cockpit of a small plane.

items.synopsis: Former US Marine pilot Daniel Duggan speaks publicly for the first time from his prison cell as he fights extradition to the United States over allegations he trained Chinese military pilots more than a decade ago.

title.children: Australian 'Top Gun' pilot speaks publicly for the first time since his arrest for allegedly training Chinese military pilots

image.altText: John margerison

items.synopsis: A businessman who has "severed all relations" with Australia and left the country is the key to unravelling accusations made under parliamentary privilege that a Canberra consulting firm planned to funnel payments to former minister Stuart Robert.

title.children: Shorten says businessman who left country is the 'key link' in Stuart Robert contracts saga

image.altText: The inside of a warehouse showing stacks of soft plastics, with some closer up.

items.synopsis: The major supermarkets have started sending samples of soft plastics overseas to be recycled, as they deal with the legacy of thousands of tonnes of stockpiled plastics from the collapsed REDcycle scheme.

title.children: Thousands of tonnes of soft plastics could be sent offshore, as supermarkets look to restart local recycling program

image.altText: A black and white graphic of a woman in profile, with a brain symbol over her head, with confused lightning shapes to her right.

items.synopsis: Imogen describes life with ADHD as "like running a race and realising you're the only one wearing weights on your ankles". She's sharing her story in the wake of a parliamentary inquiry.

title.children: Months of waiting, excessive costs, inexperienced medical staff — what it's like to get an ADHD diagnosis

image.altText: A German striker makes a phone call gesture with her hand as she receives congratulations for a goal.

items.synopsis: Alex Popp and the German team have made the biggest impression so far at the Women's World Cup — they may have plenty of bigger challenges to come, but a first title since 2007 could well be on the table, writes Kate O'Halloran.

title.children: Dominant Germany lay out impressive case for Women's World Cup favouritism

image.altText: Stocks displayed on a screen at the ASX

items.synopsis: Investors are bracing for Australia's inflation data, US tech earnings and global central bank meetings. ASIC launches court action against Vanguard. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX on the rise, ASIC takes Vanguard to court alleging greenwashing

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's a cold winter in many parts of Australia and the cost of heating your home has surged after electricity price increases this month. Research by consumer finance website Finder shows that South Australians are being worst hit by the increase in power prices with an annual estimated rise of more than $800. Here's the breakdown: South Australia: estimated price rise of 22% to 63%. A more than $800 annual increase for some customers. New South Wales: bills went up by 15% to 36%. An increase of up to $420 a year. Victoria: power prices rose by 22% to 31% with an annual price increase of up to $396. Queensland: estimated price increases of 8% to 41% with an annual price rise of $548. Saving money Finder surveyed 1,090 people and found 79% are planning to cut back on their energy usage over winter to save money. 56% plan to switch off lights and power points when not in use 54% plan to reduce use of heaters and air conditioners 21% switch to energy saving lightbulbs 9% will work from the office instead of home 9% switch electricity or gas providers Finder recommends you chose the right heater for your home and says reverse-cycle air conditioners are the cheapest to run. It also recommends that you compare and switch energy plans and look for rebates and concessions.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Power bills jump by more than $800 a year

children.content: It's a cold winter in many parts of Australia and the cost of heating your home has surged after electricity price increases this month.
Research by consumer finance website Finder shows that South Australians are being worst hit by the increase in power prices with an annual estimated rise of more than $800.
Here's the breakdown:
South Australia:
estimated price rise of 22% to 63%.
A more than $800 annual increase for some customers.
New South Wales:
bills went up by 15% to 36%.
An increase of up to $420 a year.
Victoria:
power prices rose by 22% to 31% with an annual price increase of up to $396.
Queensland:
estimated price increases of 8% to 41% with an annual price rise of $548.
Saving money
Finder surveyed 1,090 people and found 79% are planning to cut back on their energy usage over winter to save money.
56% plan to switch off lights and power points when not in use
54% plan to reduce use of heaters and air conditioners
21% switch to energy saving lightbulbs
9% will work from the office instead of home
9% switch electricity or gas providers
Finder recommends you chose the right heater for your home and says reverse-cycle air conditioners are the cheapest to run.
It also recommends that you compare and switch energy plans and look for rebates and concessions.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A few hours into trade and the local share market is still up by around 0.3 per cent, so a fairly modest gain. That's despite a really standout session for the miners, more than recouping some of the losses they posted yesterday — shares in Fortescue are up 5 per cent, Rio 's up 4.1 per cent and BHP has gained 3.8 per cent. Energy stocks are on the up, with Santos gaining 1.1 per cent so far. Despite the good performances, the gains across the broader index are being capped by falls in the financials sector — shares in Westpac have dropped 1.4 per cent. And most other sectors are posting losses as well. 119 of the top 200 stocks are in the red as it stands.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX hanging onto modest gain, Fortescue up 5%

as it stands.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you're a Spotify paid subscriber, you'll notice an extra dollar coming out of your account in coming months. Australia is one of a slew of countries being hit with the price hike by the music streaming service, which includes lifting the price of an individual premium membership from $11.99 to $12.99. Existing subscribers will get a one-month grace period before the charge increased comes out of their account. In an announcement, Spotify trumpeted its latest innovations, including its new 'AI DJ', in explaining the decision. During trade on Wall Street overnight, Spotify shares fell 4.7 per cent on the news, which comes ahead of its quarterly earnings report to be released Tuesday US time. But hey, it wasn't all bad news according to analysts from JP Morgan, who expect a 10 per cent increase in annualised revenue for the streaming giant. So out of your account and into Spotify's!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Spotify hikes prices on its premium subscription

Existing subscribers will get a one-month grace period
before the charge increased comes out of their account.
In an announcement, Spotify trumpeted its latest innovations, including its new 'AI DJ', in explaining the decision.
During trade on Wall Street overnight,
Spotify shares fell 4.7 per cent on the news
, which comes ahead of its quarterly earnings report to be released Tuesday US time.
But hey, it wasn't all bad news according to analysts from JP Morgan, who expect a 10 per cent increase in annualised revenue for the streaming giant.
So out of your account and into Spotify's!

image.altText: a man in a simple black jacket sits behind microphones

items.synopsis: China's economy is in serious trouble. The country's property sector, once a powerhouse of national economic growth, is in meltdown — and there are predictions of worse to come, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: China's economy is in serious trouble — and it's bad news for Australia

image.altText: A commercial fridge filled with Coca Cola and other soft drinks.

items.synopsis: In April, the nation's doctors called again for the introduction of a tax on sugar-sweetened drinks. They are not alone, but here's an insight into why it's still not happening, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: How the long shadow of drink giants pushes public health into the shade

image.altText: Independent candidate for Curtin Kate Chaney

items.synopsis: Legislation that would see big Commonwealth contractors banned from making political donations, and all party advertising have to pass a truth test, is set to be introduced to parliament as early as September by teal independent Kate Chaney.

title.children: 'The fight to clean up politics': Proposed new laws to shine spotlight on Australia's political donations

image.altText: A black and white image of one man holding another man's hair up.

items.synopsis: Trevor Francis, who made history as England's first player to be paid 1 million pounds, dies of a heart attack in Spain at the age of 69.

title.children: England football mourns the death of history-making star forward

image.altText: A blonde woman holds a black and white portrait of jane birkin in front of casked and pall bearers

items.synopsis: The actress, singer and inspiration for a famous handbag was farewelled by her daughters and French celebrities.

title.children: 'Jane Forever': Fans gather outside Paris funeral of singer and actress Jane Birkin

image.altText: Smoke rises over a town, turning the sky a brownish orange.

items.synopsis: Authorities say thousands of firefighters are battling to bring the flames under control after a heatwave swept across the region.

title.children: Wildfires in Algeria kill 34 people, including 10 soldiers

image.altText: A graphic of a chocolate bar, single chocolates, and Australian currency, 2023.

items.synopsis: If you think your favourite chocolate treat seems a bit more expensive than usual, you are not wrong — and analysts say factors including weather and war will keep pushing the price up.

title.children: Love chocolate? Prepare to fork out or cut back, as prices set to keep soaring

image.altText: A desk wall with a sign reading "Public health unit COVID-19. Contact tracing officer'. An out-of-focus figure sits at the desk.

items.synopsis: Third-party call centre workers contracted Victoria's health department were not properly screened, according to the state's information commissioner.

title.children: Privacy watchdog says Health Department failed to protect Victorians' data during COVID

image.altText: A young women in suit with a laptop

items.synopsis: Australia is in dire need of highly skilled researchers in the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) sector, but many report being stranded in their home country, unable to do their work here due to visa delays.

title.children: Australia is desperate for engineers like Sara — but she can't enter the country

image.altText: A man inside a man-made hole with stones around pointing at an ancient tomb with yellow sand and dirt around.

items.synopsis: Archaeologists find at least 125 tombs in a 2,000-year-old Roman cemetery discovered in Gaza last year, most with skeletons still largely intact, and two rare lead sarcophaguses.

title.children: Rare dolphin-adorned sarcophagus among tombs discovered at a Roman-era cemetery
